newScannedThrough: February 2026 — scanned 2026 Global Outlook Conference, January 2026 AI/labor research briefing, and 2026 economic trend reports

newContent.title: Evidence of an AI-driven shakeup of job markets is patchy
keyFindings: Firms don't appear to be replacing workers with AI on a significant scale
AI cited for 55,000 US job cuts in first 11 months of 2025 — only 4.5% of total job losses
Job losses from 'market/economic conditions' were 4x larger (245,000)
Some firms may be 'dressing up layoffs as good news' by attributing to AI
If AI were replacing labor at scale, productivity should be accelerating — it isn't
Graduate unemployment rise aligns with cyclical patterns, not AI-driven structural change

newContent.title: Three key trends to watch in the global economy in 2026
keyFindings: AI as 'shock absorber or shock magnifier' for 2026 growth
Rapid US AI-related capital spending has offset weaker growth elsewhere
AI financing shifting from cash to debt — creating vulnerability
Upside scenario: tech spending hits record % of GDP, US GDP grows 3%
Downside scenario: dot-com-style bust could drop US GDP growth below 1%

newContent.title: Dispatches from Oxford Economics' 2026 Global Outlook Conference: AI, tariffs and the new shape of growth
keyFindings: Adrian Cooper: 'Protectionism will continue to creep higher, and AI will remain the vital counterweight'
Global trade in 'tug-of-war between tariffs and AI'
AI-driven investment keeps high-tech manufacturing buoyant despite tariff pressures

newContent.title: 2026 Labor Market Outlook (via Fortune/Yahoo coverage)
keyFindings: Job gains to average less than 40,000/month in 2026 — enough to keep unemployment stable
Michael Pearce: Economy will grow via higher productivity aided by AI, but 'people aren't core to that story'
AI's labor-saving potential could boost corporate profits as share of economy
Workers may account for smaller slice of economic gains

summary: First scan of Oxford Economics AI/labor research. Major January 2026 research briefing challenges AI job displacement narrative — finds only 4.5% of US job losses attributed to AI, suggests companies use AI as 'cover story' for routine layoffs. Key organizational insight: the productivity test (if AI were displacing workers, productivity should accelerate — it isn't). February 2026 outlook predicts 'jobless expansion' where growth comes from AI-enabled productivity gains rather than hiring. Relevant to structural research: evidence that AI workforce transformation is slower than corporate narratives suggest, with firms in 'low-hire, low-fire' equilibrium.

specimenImplications.signal: AI displacement narrative vs. reality gap — Oxford Economics finds corporate AI-layoff claims outpace actual AI-driven job losses by ~20:1
specimenImplications.relevance: Challenges specimen claims about AI workforce transformation; suggests need for skepticism about AI-attributed layoffs in press releases

specimenImplications.signal: 'Low-hire, low-fire' equilibrium — firms not aggressively adding or cutting workers as AI capabilities expand
specimenImplications.relevance: Suggests most organizations are in holding pattern, not rapid workforce restructuring; specimen evidence of aggressive AI-driven layoffs may be outliers

specimenImplications.mechanism: AI as corporate narrative device — layoffs attributed to AI may serve signaling function (forward-looking, tech-savvy) rather than reflecting actual automation
specimenImplications.relevance: Caution when interpreting specimen workforce changes; triangulate with productivity metrics
